channel.title: My messenger
channel.description:
Umm.. this is just a messenger that I made for an RS Private Server that they wanted to have running alongside with their Server...
I'm sure none of you want to but you can go ahead and just check it out, it saves the users configuration when you exit, it has commands: [code] /ipban - ip ban someone /ban - ban someone /kick - kick someone /isOn - I think shows how many people are online, I dont remember if I removed that or not /server - checks the server status (they had 2 servers) /restart - restarts the server /setpass newpass, oldpass - or oldpass, newpass, i forgot but it changes your pass. [/code]
Well, you can go ahead and use its LAF if you want to, got it from SourceForge.net and take no credit for it.
Oh, it supports 1 on 1 chat, also I added a small feature: You can close out of the main window if you are talking to someone 1 on 1, when you close all the 1 on 1 windows it will open the main chat window again, then you close that to disconnect.
Idk if I forgot everything, tell me what you think (its pretty large).
[b]Download:[/b]
[url=http://uppit.com/0ZV65D]Server[/url] [url=http://uppit.com/ZJNTO0]Client[/url]
BTW, RUN RUN.bat AND JAR THE CLIENT :D
[IMG]http://i29.tinypic.com/2ch9ieb.jpg[/img]

item.title: My messenger
item.dc:creator: @pizza_pie pizza pie
item.description:
@pizza_pie wrote:

[quote=“Uriko, post:17, topic:212577”][quote author=pizza pie link=topic=279952.msg2281163#msg2281163 date=1213698496]
Internet Relay Chat… Instant Messaging… both used for real-time text transferring or something.
[/quote]different protocol, and you said an IRC bot, not an IRC client.[/quote]Oh yah. My bad.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: June 19, 2008, 05:42:25 PM[/size][hr]Hey, sorry for being an idiot but I’m just lazy and I want to ask the following:

  1. Does InputStream keep the bytes that it has received there for you to read later? Say I’m reading from one InputStream and another InputStream receives a message, will I be able to read the message from the other InputStream when I’m done reading from the current one?

  2. Also, can someone show me an example server that does not create a new Thread for every new connection. I’ve been looking for a while now and all I see is those. Also, I haven’t InputStream ever… so an example would be nice

Thanks.

Read full topic

item.title: My messenger
item.dc:creator: @VB7_Rocks VB7 Rocks
item.description:
@VB7_Rocks wrote:

IIRC, Socket has a getInetAddress() method that returns the remote computer’s IP. I think that would help you to create a better ban system, other than one based on computer hostnames.

Read full topic

item.title: My messenger
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

pizza pie:

if this was something worth exploiting, it would have been done a long time ago.

its not being exploited for two reasons

  1. you released it just a few days ago
  2. noone is actively running a server, and advertising its domain/ip address (as far as i know)

if i find you or anyone running it, ill exploit it like i said just to teach you guys a lesson,
take security seriously or you’ll end up like microsoft,

pizza pie:

As for every new Thread for each new connection, how would you suggest I do it?

one way is like this,

clients is an instance of List which holds your client socket input streams

for(InputStream in : clients) {
    if(in.available() > 0) {
        //read from socket
    }
}

although thats only one way, and im not too sure of it,
if you’re serious about it, google for an open source java server of some sort, and see how it handles many clients,

pizza pie:

And the reason i’m not catching those exceptions is because i’m not expecting anything else to connect to my server.

these are the kind of assumsions which are not justified, they will be used against you,
not just in servers, but any application should be robust, having an uncaught exception like that is just asking for trouble,

btw, why isnt NumberFormatException a checked exception? it really should be,

[quote=“pizza pie, post:9, topic:212577”]EDIT:
isnt localhost like 127.0.0.1 and 0.0.0.0, also, i get the computer name because if you checked, it sends something like this:
computerName/temporaryIP

I take the computer name and use that as an ip [size=10pt]becuase it never changes[/size], and its an easy way to find out peoples computer names, therefore making me cool[/quote]

its official people! a computers domain name never changes!

you dont look cool now my friend, you look a prick who doesnt take peoples advice on board, and ends up writing insecure stuff

pizza pie, you obviously have a lot to learn,
you can change your computers domain name by editing the “/etc/hostname” file, or whatever the windows equivalent is,

even if the computers name was impossible to change, you still fail by asking the client to provide it,
there is absolutly nothing stopping the client from sending a completely fake computer name, its a really simple and easy way to get around your ban,

Read full topic

item.title: My messenger
item.dc:creator: @pizza_pie pizza pie
item.description:
@pizza_pie wrote:

Wow yakman. I guess I didn’t think about security lol, you’re right if this was something worth exploiting, it would have been done a long time ago.

As for every new Thread for each new connection, how would you suggest I do it?

And the reason i’m not catching those exceptions is because i’m not expecting anything else to connect to my server.

Plz answer my questions and thanks for your feedback

EDIT:
isnt localhost like 127.0.0.1 and 0.0.0.0, also, i get the computer name because if you checked, it sends something like this:
computerName/temporaryIP

I take the computer name and use that as an ip becuase it never changes, and its an easy way to find out peoples computer names, therefore making me cool

Read full topic

item.title: My messenger
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

yakman:

i wonder if runescape private servers are vulnerable to similar stuff,

many things:

  • appearance based dos
  • (in game) area based dos
  • arbitrary privilege escalation
  • buffer overflow
  • rapid increase of memory usage (leading to dos)

Read full topic

item.title: My messenger
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

why dont you keep the libraries you use in their jar files, no need to extract them, you’re probably going to say “i need to jar them”, well just use http://one-jar.sourceforge.net/

also, why are all your fields all the way at the bottom? its really annoying to read, fields should be the first thing you see

and where do you actually use the jdom library, iv looked and i cant find any reference to it, you just seem to use newline-seperated data, read with BufferedReader…

you program isnt very robust,

				case 10: //player rights
					playerRights = Integer.parseInt(message);
				break;

what happens if the message received is not parseable as an integer?
answer: it will crash that thread and stop the client working,
when working with network programming, you should never ever trust the program on the other side of the connection, this is the most important place to have sanity checks for everything, check every return value, catch every exception, and if you detect any foul play, disconnect the program,

its obvious you didnt write this program with security in mind,
ok thats unfair, you have things like ban, kick and so on, but they are for security against idiots who only use your program, you need to defend against programmers who know what they are doing, and an ip ban wont stop them,

another thing,
you open a new thread for every client, which uses so much cpu and is just begging to be exploited,
you have an array of sockets of length 500, but your server would crash long before it gets to that limit,

and another thing, in your protocol, your server actually asks the client what its ip address is! and it uses it as the basis of a security-related feature, its ip ban.
what happens when a client replies, “my ip is 10.10.10.10”, are you going to ban that?
use socket.getInetAddress() to find out the client’s ip address, it asks a trustworthy source (the kernel) what the ip is

also, on the client-side

				case 6: //ip request
					try {
						String IP = InetAddress.getLocalHost()+"";
						IP = IP.substring(0, IP.indexOf("/"));
						write("3 " +IP);
					} catch(Exception e) { }
				break;

that always returns localhost/127.0.0.1, you need to use the java.net.NetworkInterface class

another security flaw is the way you use the BufferedReader class by reading directly from the connection, that class reads from a stream and stores it into a buffer, when it encounters a newline or EOF, it returns the buffer,

so what happens if the client never sends a newline?
i dont remember the details of the BufferedReader class, but i bet its internal buffer grows and grows, until your machine runs out or core memory, and it crashes the server,
it would be very simple, just open a connection to your server, and send the same byte,
i would personally prefer the A char,



some people might have a sense of humour, and send a small message, like “YOUGOTOWNDYOUGOTOWNDYOUGOTOWND”

your main problem is you simply didnt build this with security in mind,
for the client, it isnt that important, but for a server application, its paramount,

any skiddie could make your server go down like the twin towers, in the real world, it doesnt stand a chance,

whenever you offer any kind of service on the internet, that service could be a http server, a website, a forum, a chat-server like this one, or even an irc channel, you must have enough knowledge to be able to defend yourself,
i wonder if runescape private servers are vulnerable to similar stuff,

maybe im being a bit too harsh, you’ll probably never use this in the real world, but im guessing you didnt know about the security issue, i would have been alright if you posted this thread saying “i know the security isnt that good, but it wasnt my concern, so what do you think of the logic/speed of this program?”

Read full topic

item.title: My messenger
item.dc:creator: @pizza_pie pizza pie
item.description:
@pizza_pie wrote:

[quote=“TeleNubby, post:2, topic:212577”][code]
private String getSmileys(String str) {
str = str.replaceAll(":rip:", “”);
str = str.replaceAll(":hug:", “”);
str = str.replaceAll(":crazy:", “”);
str = str.replaceAll("", “”);
str = str.replaceAll(":music:", “<img src='http://www.freesmileys.org/emo/basic/stereo.gif>”);
str = str.replaceAll(":welcome:", “”);
str = str.replaceAll(":<", “”);
str = str.replaceAll(":q:", “”);
str = str.replaceAll(":Q:", “”);
str = str.replaceAll(":D", “”);
str = str.replaceAll(":d", “”);
str = str.replaceAll(":@", “”);
str = str.replaceAll(":P", “”);
str = str.replaceAll(":S", “”);
str = str.replaceAll(":p", “”);
str = str.replaceAll(":s", “”);
str = str.replaceAll(":z", “”);
str = str.replaceAll(":Z", “”);

	while(str.indexOf(":)") > -1) {
		String smiley = str.substring(0, str.indexOf(":)"));
		String replace = "<img src='http://www.xs4all.nl/~ernstmul/images/msn60/smile001.gif'>";
		
		StringBuilder build = new StringBuilder().append(smiley).append(replace).append(str.substring(str.indexOf(":)") + 2));
		str = build.toString();
	}
	
	while(str.indexOf(":(") > -1) {
		String smiley = str.substring(0, str.indexOf(":("));
		String replace = "<img src='http://www.xs4all.nl/~ernstmul/images/msn60/smile003.gif'>";
		
		StringBuilder build = new StringBuilder().append(smiley).append(replace).append(str.substring(str.indexOf(":(") + 2));
		str = build.toString();
	}
		
	return str;
}

[/code]
Ew @ hardcoding. You used your JDOM library for other purposes, why not for this one? (For those of you who dont know, JDOM is an XML parser in Java.)

Anyways, it’s not bad. But you did use NetBeans for the GUI part, am I correct?[/quote]Rofl I’m sorry you had to see that
I was planning on taking it out and replacing it with images I create and just uploading those along with the client, but I was like, screw that, no smileys! Lol, if you didnt notice the getSmileys() method is never called…

Yah I used NetBeans for the GUI part.

@Unhandled - Lol, I really don’t care

Read full topic

item.title: My messenger
item.dc:creator: @TeleNubby TeleNubby
item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

	private String getSmileys(String str) {
		str = str.replaceAll(":rip:", "<img src='http://www.freesmileys.org/emo/basic/rip.gif'>");
		str = str.replaceAll(":hug:", "<img scr='http://www.freesmileys.org/emo/basic/hug.gif'>");
		str = str.replaceAll(":crazy:", "<img src='http://www.freesmileys.org/emo/basic/excited.gif'>");
		str = str.replaceAll(":rofl:", "<img src='http://www.freesmileys.org/emo/basic/rofl.gif'>");
		str = str.replaceAll(":music:", "<img src='http://www.freesmileys.org/emo/basic/stereo.gif>");
		str = str.replaceAll(":welcome:", "<img src='http://www.freesmileys.org/emo/basic/welcome.gif'>");
		str = str.replaceAll(":<", "<img src='http://www.freesmileys.org/emo/basic/sick.gif'>");
		str = str.replaceAll(":q:", "<img src='http://www.freesmileys.org/emo/basic/what.gif'>");
		str = str.replaceAll(":Q:", "<img src='http://www.freesmileys.org/emo/basic/what.gif'>");
		str = str.replaceAll(":D", "<img src='http://www.xs4all.nl/~ernstmul/images/msn60/smile002.gif'>");
		str = str.replaceAll(":d", "<img src='http://www.xs4all.nl/~ernstmul/images/msn60/smile002.gif'>");
		str = str.replaceAll(":@", "<img src='http://www.freesmileys.org/emo/basic/rant.gif'>");
		str = str.replaceAll(":P", "<img src='http://www.xs4all.nl/~ernstmul/images/msn60/smile007.gif'>");
		str = str.replaceAll(":S", "<img src='http://www.xs4all.nl/~ernstmul/images/msn60/smile005.gif'>");
		str = str.replaceAll(":p", "<img src='http://www.xs4all.nl/~ernstmul/images/msn60/smile007.gif'>");
		str = str.replaceAll(":s", "<img src='http://www.xs4all.nl/~ernstmul/images/msn60/smile005.gif'>");
		str = str.replaceAll(":z", "<img src='http://www.freesmileys.org/emo/basic/sleep.gif'>");
		str = str.replaceAll(":Z", "<img src='http://www.freesmileys.org/emo/basic/sleep.gif'>");

		while(str.indexOf(":)") > -1) {
			String smiley = str.substring(0, str.indexOf(":)"));
			String replace = "<img src='http://www.xs4all.nl/~ernstmul/images/msn60/smile001.gif'>";
			
			StringBuilder build = new StringBuilder().append(smiley).append(replace).append(str.substring(str.indexOf(":)") + 2));
			str = build.toString();
		}
		
		while(str.indexOf(":(") > -1) {
			String smiley = str.substring(0, str.indexOf(":("));
			String replace = "<img src='http://www.xs4all.nl/~ernstmul/images/msn60/smile003.gif'>";
			
			StringBuilder build = new StringBuilder().append(smiley).append(replace).append(str.substring(str.indexOf(":(") + 2));
			str = build.toString();
		}
			
		return str;
	}

Ew @ hardcoding. You used your JDOM library for other purposes, why not for this one? (For those of you who dont know, JDOM is an XML parser in Java.)

Anyways, it’s not bad. But you did use NetBeans for the GUI part, am I correct?

Read full topic

item.title: My messenger
item.dc:creator: @pizza_pie pizza pie
item.description:
@pizza_pie wrote:

Umm… this is just a messenger that I made for an RS Private Server that they wanted to have running alongside with their Server…

I’m sure none of you want to but you can go ahead and just check it out, it saves the users configuration when you exit, it has commands:

/ipban - ip ban someone
/ban - ban someone
/kick - kick someone
/isOn - I think shows how many people are online, I dont remember if I removed that or not
/server - checks the server status (they had 2 servers)
/restart - restarts the server
/setpass newpass, oldpass - or oldpass, newpass, i forgot but it changes your pass.

Well, you can go ahead and use its LAF if you want to, got it from SourceForge.net and take no credit for it.

Oh, it supports 1 on 1 chat, also I added a small feature: You can close out of the main window if you are talking to someone 1 on 1, when you close all the 1 on 1 windows it will open the main chat window again, then you close that to disconnect.

Idk if I forgot everything, tell me what you think (its pretty large).

Download:

Server
Client

BTW, RUN RUN.bat AND JAR THE CLIENT
